key_mistakes.reason: This move allowed White to maintain an advanced pawn on e5 without any immediate pressure. Black should have played d5 to challenge White's center.
Playing Qe7 blocks the bishop's development and doesn't address the problem of White's advanced pawn. Black should have challenged the center with d5.
This move puts the queen in a vulnerable position where it can be easily attacked by White's pieces. It also doesn't develop any other pieces.
This move captures a pawn but puts the queen in a dangerous position where it can be easily trapped and attacked.
This move unnecessarily places the knight in a position where it can be attacked, missing the opportunity to defend or counter-attack.
This move weakens the pawn structure and allows Black's queen to penetrate White's position.
This move puts the queen on the side of the board where it is less active and more vulnerable.
This move fails to address the pressure on the e5 pawn and misses an opportunity to counter-attack.
Fails to create threats or improve Black's position, allowing White to seize the initiative.
This move opens the kingside and weakens Black's pawn structure, giving White a significant advantage.

recommendations: Focus on controlling the center in the opening to gain a strong position.
Develop pieces efficiently instead of moving the queen early.
Ensure king safety by avoiding moves that expose the king.
Look for opportunities to counter-attack rather than just defending.
